Process Description and Regulated Substances - §68.155(b)

Reaction Technology Epi, LLC is an international manufacturer and supplier of high quality Cz-silicon wafers for the semiconductor industry.  The facility is located at 301 Ridgemont Dr., Allen, Texas 75002.  The SIC code for the operation is 3674; the NAICS code is 334413.  The facility currently employs about 43 persons at this facility.  

The manufacturing process is epitaxial deposition using chemical vapor deposition (CVD) technology in which the silicon and dopants are brought to the single crystal surface by gaseous transport.  Epitaxy refers to the deposition of a crystalline over-layer on a crystalline substrate.  The over-layer is called the epitaxial film or epitaxial layer.

The process utilizes Trichlorosilane (TCS) as the source of silicon for the wafer deposition.  The deposition takes place in an epitaxial reactor operated at elevated temperatures.  The temperature is high enough to separate the silicon and chlorine atoms contained in the Trichlorosilane.  The dopant gases Arsine, Phosphine and Diborane also decompose at operating temperatures and are the source of the doping metals (Arsenic, Phosphorous or Boron) used in the process to create the desired characteristics of the final product.  

Hydrogen Chloride is used to remove silicon and dopant metal deposits on the reactor internal surfaces that accumulate during the reaction cycle.  Hydrogen chloride is also a major by-product of the deposition process.  HCL emissions are controlled in accordance with applicable state and federal air regulations.  The facility has obtained a permit from the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality for the emissions from the process.

Silicon substrates are used to produce silicon wafers for manufacturing a variety semiconductor products.

The facility operates bulk Hydrogen Chloride (HCL) and Trichlorosilane (TCS) storage and distribution systems that supply the CVD epitaxial manufacturing process.

Hydrogen Chloride (HCL) is a highly corrosive gas that will quickly combine with water vapor in the air to form Hydrochloric Acid.  The acid will quickly react and form less harmful chloride salts and water in the environment.  The above reactions occur quickly in the environment thus the reactive effects of a release will end shortly (within minutes to a few hours) of the time when the release stops.  The system consists of bulk storage and distribution piping and equipment.  The maximum inventory of HCL on site exceeds the reporting threshold for RMP.  

HCL gas is withdrawn from the storage tanks through a series of regulators and automatic valves equipped with monitors, alarms, and automatic shutdowns that vent to gas scrubbers should there be any leaks.  Additionally, HCL gas is only withdrawn from the storage tanks as it is used.  This minimizes the amount of gas that would be released from using the system.  The pressure of the gas in the distribution system is kept relatively low to reduce the potential for leaks in the distribution system.  The distribution system is constructed using corrosion resistant Hastelloy steel, with welded connections where possible, valve enclosures vented through scrubbers, purge systems vented through scrubbers, alarms with automatic shutdowns, manual shutdowns, and employee training.  

Trichlorosilane (TCS) is a colorless volatile liquid that is corrosive and extremely flammable.  TCS reacts with water to form corrosive compounds and may ignite on contact with water or air.

 
The TCS system consists of bulk liquid supply and distribution piping and equipment.  Liquid transfer is accomplished by pressurizing the bulk storage container vapor space with inert gas (argon).  The increased pressure forces the TCS into the distribution piping via a dip tube installed in the vessel.  When the active container is depleted, the system automatically switches to an alternate supply, typically a 55-gallon secondary supply source located

in the distribution system cabinet and warns the operator that the empty bulk container needs to be exchanged.  

TCS is received at the facility in a cargo transport vessel.  It remains in the transport vessel at the facility.  No bulk liquid transfer is conducted at the facility.  Empty cargo containers are exchanged, as needed.  During container change out, the system piping and electrical controls function to first clear the lines of residual TCS to allow the empty cargo vessel to be safely disconnected, and second to check system integrity and cleanliness once a new container has been connected.  The operator works in conjunction with the microprocessor program to accomplish these tasks.  Trained representatives from the product supplier conduct these operations.

Liquid from the supply vessel is routed through a manifold system to the process.  At the use points, the TCS is contacted with a carrier gas, typically Hydrogen, to provide vapor phase feed to a reaction chamber. Maximum intended inventory at the facility exceeds the reporting threshold for RMP.

Five Year Accident History - §68.155(d)

There are no known accidents or releases associated with the ammonia refrigeration system within the past five years which resulted in deaths, injuries, significant property damage, environmental damage, or evacuations, either onsite or off-site.

Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies - §68.155(a)

The facility has evaluated and reported one worst case scenario and has evaluated alternate scenarios and reported one which will result in an offsite impact that is more likely to occur than the worst case scenario.

The supplier of both distribution systems has incorporated safety provisions that include numerous alarms, automatic shutdowns, and employee procedures designed to insure that the HCL and TCS is safely stored and used in the process.  All system components are designed in accordance with the applicable guidelines and recommendations of the America

n Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME), The American National Standards Institute (ANSI), The Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), and other appropriate industry standards for compressed gases and semiconductor facilities.  Reaction Technology Epi is committed to immediate response and full cooperation with the authorities in the event of any kind of emergency situation at the facility.

Both TCS and HCL bulk delivery systems are equipped with detection sensors connected to a site wide Toxic Gas Monitoring system with shutdown capabilities in the event of a leak.  In addition, restrictive flow orifices and excess flow detection, low-low and high-high detection systems are in place with shutdown capabilities.  The TCS bulk delivery area is further protected with an AFFF foam suppression system, 14 ft. high fire walls, and 110% secondary containment.  Any loss of exhaust detected at any gas cabinet or reactor will result in shutdown of the source gas.  Bollards are in place at both bulk delivery areas to prevent damage due to vehicular traffic.

The company has taken every reasonable precaution to insure that any release is small.  The bulk storage vessels for HCL and TCS are protected DOT approved shipping containers.  They represent a very low risk of releasing a regulated substance.  
 
Air Products and Chemicals, Inc. (APCI) is the supplier of the HCL and TCS bulk storage and distribution systems.  Procedures developed and provided by APCI are used for the system.  Reaction Technology Epi employees are involved in all chemical supply change outs and associated work.  

Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps - §68.155(a)

Reaction Technology Epi and the product supplier have developed and implemented Process Safety Management Programs in accordance with the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Standard, 29 CFR 1910.119 for Hydrogen Chloride and Trichlorosilane in order to eliminate or minimize

releases from the facility.  This serves as the prevention plan required by RMP.  The facility has also developed and implemented procedures for safe work practices including control of hazardous energy.  The PSM program is reviewed annually and updated as necessary.  All significant changes to the system are reviewed in accordance with the PSM / RMP management of change provisions in the facility's plan.

Emergency Response Program - §68.155(e)

The facility has made arrangements with the local fire department or outside contractors to respond to emergencies involving hydrogen chloride and/or trichlorosilane.  The facility conducts periodic incident response drills.  The facility has never experienced a release that resulted in employee, contractor or off-site injuries, or offsite evacuation or sheltering in place.  Facility personnel are trained to safely control small, incidental releases, in the event they should occur.

The facility has complied with the requirements of section 302 and 303 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right to Know Act (EPCRA) by notifying the State Emergency Response Commission (SERC), the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC), and the Fire Department of the presence of hydrogen chloride and trichlorosilane at the site.  The facility files a Tier 2 Chemical Inventory each year with the SERC, LEPC and the Fire Department as required by sections 311 and 312 of EPCRA.  The facility's Emergency Action Plan includes procedures for notifying the proper agencies in the event of a reportable release of ammonia.  A hydrogen chloride release of 5000 pounds or more or a release that creates an offsite impact must be reported to the National Response Center, the SERC, and LEPC, in accordance with section 304 of EPCRA.  The Fire Department will be provided with a copy of the facility's Emergency Action Plan upon request.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety - §68.155(f)

The prevention plan includes routine and periodic inspections and audits

of the process and prevention programs to identify potential deficiencies.  The Process Hazard Analyses are conducted initially, as part of major additions or modifications and every five years to identify potential hazards in the process and provide recommendations to eliminate or reduce hazards and improve process safety and efficiency.
